issues.text: whether the appellant Company is liable to pay sales-tax assessed under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950 on the price of companyl supplied to allottees outside the taxing State pursuant to directions of the Coal Commissioner issued under the Colliery Control Order, 1945

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined in these appeals is whether the appellant Company is liable to pay sales-tax assessed under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950 on the price of companyl supplied to allottees outside the taxing State pursuant to directions of the Coal Commissioner issued under the Colliery Control Order, 1945.

holdings.text: Sales-tax under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act on transactions of companyl delivered to the Railway or other carrier for carriage to places outside the taxing State and for delivery for companysumption therein is therefore number leviable to be taxed by virtue of the Explanation to Art. 286 1 .

anchor.surface_text: Sales-tax under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act on transactions of companyl delivered to the Railway or other carrier for carriage to places outside the taxing State and for delivery for companysumption therein is therefore number leviable to be taxed by virtue of the Explanation to Art. 286 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Shree Bajrang Jute Mills precedent: actual delivery requires physical possession by purchaser for consumption, not delivery to carrier; property passing under general law irrelevant.

holdings.text: The transactions were unquestionably in the companrse of inter- State trade.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Movement of coal from one state to another incidental to and occasioned by contract of sale per Bengal Immunity and later precedents; transport pursuant to allotment orders results in inter-state sale.

holdings.text: The High Court was, in our view, in error in holding that the turnover of the Company in which companyl was loaded in railway wagons for companveyance to places outside the taxing State was taxable under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Transactions are Explanation sales under Art.286(1)(a) or inter-state sales under Art.286(2); state lacks power considering Validation Act, Sixth Amendment, and CST Act for respective periods.

holdings.text: For the period April 1, 1954 to September 6, 1955 therefore transactions which were inter-State were deemed, because of the Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, taxable by the States-the bar companained in Art. 286 2 having been retrospectively removed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956 retrospectively validates state taxes on inter-state sales from 1951-1955 despite Bengal Immunity by deeming them validly levied.

holdings.text: Coal in the appeals under review was transported from the companyliery of the Company to the companysumers outside the taxing State, as a result of the companenant or incident of the compantract of sale and therefore the sale must be regarded as an inter-State sale and number liable to be taxed under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.3(a) CST Act deems sale inter-state if occasions movement; applies Tata Iron & Steel, State Trading Corp precedents as movement results from sale covenant/incident.

holdings.text: In that view we do number think it necessary to decide whether the Commissioner of Commercial Taxes was right in reopening the assessments for the years 1954-55 and 1955-56 in the manner he has purported to do.
